facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 7, 1958 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 456 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 7, 1958 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 456 of 1957. P . Ram Reddy for the appellants.

facts.text: High Court convicted the two appellants of an offence under s. 380 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced them to six months rigorous imprisonment and a fine Rs. 500/- each, with further rigorous imprisonment for one month in default.

anchor.surface_text: High Court of Andhra Pradesh convicting them, on appeal against acquittal, of an offence under. 380 of the Indian Penal Code and sentencing them to six months rigorous imprisonment and a fine Rs. 500/- each, with further rigorous impriso

facts.text: Srinivasa Printing Press existed for over 17 years at Srinivasa Ashram in Dusi, part of Bhaskararaopuram.

anchor.surface_text: In Dusi, which is a part of Bhaskararaopuram, there was a Press known as Srinivasa Printing Press at Srinivasa Ashram. This Press existed for over 17 years.

facts.text: Pappala Chinna Ramadasu PW.4 was the declared keeper of the Press under s. 4 of the Press and Registration of Books Act, 1867 with declarations in 1944 Ex.P.4 and 1947 Ex.P-5.

anchor.surface_text: Pappala Chinna Ramadasu  P.W.4  was admittedly a printer and for some years, the declared keeper of that Press under s. 4 of the Press and Registration of Books Act, 1867. The declarations were made in 1944  Ex.P.4  and 1947  Ex.P-5 .

facts.text: Pappala Chinna Ramadasu sold the press by registered document Ex.P.1 to Boddepalli Lakshminarayana for Rs 4,000/- on November 21, 1955, Rs.3,500/- paid in advance, balance received on January 10, 1956 Ex.P.2.

anchor.surface_text: On November 21, 1955, Pappala Chinna Ramadasu sold this press by a registered document  Ex.P. 1   to one Boddepalli Lakshminarayana for Rs 4,000/-, of which Rs.3,500/- were shown to have been paid in advance and the balance was received by Pa

facts.text: Two applications made on December 1, 1955 by Chinna Ramadasu and Boddepalli Lakshminarayana to Collector for substituting name.

anchor.surface_text: Two applications were then made on December 1, 1955, respectively by Chinna Ramadasu and Boddepalli Lakshminarayana before the Collector and District Magistrate for substituting the name of Boddepalli Lakshminarayana in place of that of Pappala

facts.text: On December 6, 1955 informed by Ex.P.11 to apply under Press and Registration of Books Act 25 of 1867.

anchor.surface_text: On December 6, 1955, by Ex. P.11 they were informed that they should apply under the Press and Registration of Books Act  25 of 1867 .

facts.text: Declaration under s.4 made by Boddepalli Lakshminarayana on January 11, 1956 accepted Ex.P.3.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, on January 11, 1956, a declaration under s. 4 of that Act was made by Boddepalli Lakshminarayana and was accepted  Ex.P.3 .

facts.text: Boddepalli Lakshminarayana went to Kurnool on March 20, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the prosecution further is that Boddepalli Lakshminarayana went to Kurnool on March 20, 1956, and in his absence,

facts.text: Two appellants with two others removed the Printing Press on the night of March 25, 1956 to Korlakota where first appellant Apparao resides.

anchor.surface_text: the two appellants with two others  who were prosecuted but acquitted  removed the Printing Press on the night of March 25, 1956 to Korlakota where the first appellant, Apparao, resides.

facts.text: Report of offence Ex.P-13 purporting to be written on March 27, 1956 handed at police station on following day at 8 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: A report of the offence  Ex.P-13 , purporting to be written on March 27, 1956, was handed in at the police station house on the following day at 8 P.m.

facts.text: Companyplaint filed on April 4, 1956 by Boddepalli Lakshminarayana.

anchor.surface_text: The police took no action, and a complaint was, therefore, filed on April 4, 1956, by Boddepalli Laksminarayana.

facts.text: Judicial Second Class Magistrate Srikakulam convicted two appellants u/s 380 IPC, sentenced to imprisonment till rising of Court and fine Rs.250/-, default one month SI, acquitted two others.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Second class Magistrate, Srikakulam, convicted the two appellants of an offence under s. 380 of the Indian Penal Code, and acquitted the two others, with whom we are not concerned, and sentenced each of the appellants to impriso

facts.text: Additional District and Sessions Judge Srikakulam set aside conviction and acquitted appellants on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Additional District and Sessions Judge, Srikakulam, set aside the conviction and acquitted them.

facts.text: Complainant obtained special leave of High Court to appeal against acquittal, High Court reversed acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: The complainant then obtained special leave of the High Court to file appeal against this acquittal, and the High Court reversed the acquittal, as already indicated above.

facts.text: Press originally belonged to Govindachari, transferred on October 25, 1947 to Kuna Appala Naidu by Ex.D-2, Pappala Chinna Ramadasu joined formally.

anchor.surface_text: According to them, the Press originally belonged to one Govindachari, and on October 25, 1947 he transferred it to Kuna Appala Naidu by Ex. D-2. In the registered sale deed then executed, Govindachari was joined formally by Pappala Chinna

facts.text: Sale for Rs. 6,400/- and promissory note executed same day by Kuna Appala Naidu in favour of Govindachari, attested by Pappala Chinna Ramadasu.

anchor.surface_text: The sale was for Rs. 6,400/- and on the same day, a promissory note was executed by Kuna Appala Naidu in favour of Govindachari, which was attested by Pappala Chinna Ramadasu.

facts.text: Kuna Appala Naidu later sold the Press to the second appellant and one Sri K. Sriramulu, second appellant continued in possession as owner.

anchor.surface_text: Kuna Appala Naidu later sold the Press to the second appellant and one Sri K. Sriramda, and the second appellant continued in possession as owner.

facts.text: Pappala Chinna Ramadasu continued as printer, left the Press for good in 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Pappala Chinna Ramadas continued as the printer, and his declaration as the keeper of the Press also continued. In 1953, Pappala Chinna Ramadasu left the Press for good.

facts.text: Press leased by second appellant to Appanna till 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Press was leased out by the second appellant to one Appanna, and this lease continued till 1956.

facts.text: Agreement for lease executed on March 19, 1956 in favour of first appellant, registered deed on March 26, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On March 19, 1956, an agreement for lease was executed in favour of the first appellant, and on March 26, 1956, a registered deed was duly executed.

facts.text: Press removed during the day on March 27, 1956, lease amount paid on 28th.

facts.text: Akkala Naidu died in 1951.

anchor.surface_text: He also stated that his father had died in 1951.

facts.text: High Court Judge said nothing about Ex.D-2.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge of the High Court, who heard the appeal against the acquittal, said nothing about Ex. D-2.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that bona fide claim of right is a good defence to prosecution for theft.

anchor.surface_text: It is settled law that where a bona fide claim of right exists, it can be a good defence to a prosecution for theft. An act does not amount to theft, unless there be not only no legal right but no appearance or colour of a legal right.

facts.text: Supreme Court acquitted the appellants, set aside convictions and sentences.

issues.text: Whether a bona fide claim of right is a good defence to a prosecution for theft?

anchor.surface_text: It is settled law that where a bona fide claim of right exists, it can be a good defence to a prosecution for theft. An act does not amount to theft, unless there be not only no legal right but no appearance or colour of a legal right.

issues.text: Whether a declared keeper of the press under section 4 of the Press and Registration of Books Act is necessarily the owner thereof?

anchor.surface_text: We are not concerned in this case with the declaration under the Press and Registration of Books Act. A declared keeper of the Press is not necessarily the owner thereof so as to be able to confer title to the Press upon another.

anchor.surface_text: It is settled law that where a bona fide claim of right exists, it can be a good defence to a prosecution for theft. An act does not amount to theft, unless there be not only no legal right but no appearance or colour of a legal right.
